en.sc1: student and course entities with many to many relationship.
en.sc2: These are the tables before any student registration.
en.sc3: Assume that Ali registers in Database course.
en.sc5: Insert Ali's id in the bridge.
en.sc7: Insert Database course code in the bridge so as to record ali's registration in Database course.
en.sc8: Ali also registered in java course.
en.sc9: The same student Ali with the same id (201) will register in another course.
en.sc10: Insert Ali's id (201) again in the bridge along with java course code in the same record in the bridge to save that registration transaction.
en.sc12: Now, Ali's registration in java is recorded in the bridge
en.sc13: Then Mona needs to reigister in Java course new empty record is added to the bridge to save her registration data.
en.sc15: Insert mona's id in the new record in the bridge
en.sc17: java course code should be inserted beside mona's id in the bridge as shown.
en.sc18: Layla will register in Math course.
en.sc20: Insert layla's id in a new record in the bridge to record new student registration transaction.
en.sc22: Math course code also inserted with layla's id in the bridge.
en.sc23: Layla will register in Database course.
en.sc24: Finally layla's registraion in Database course saved the same way by inserting new record containing her id and database course code in the bridge.
en.sc25: Any Binary N:M relationship decomposed to two 1:M relationships between the two original tables and the new bridge.
